1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.
We at the Rock Island Water Tratment Plant are committed to employee, public, and environmental saftey. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the Chlorine process at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of chlorine. If, inforeseeably, such a release does occur, we are completely coordinated with the Rock Island Fire Department, which provides trained response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of the release.
2.The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled.
We have 1 regulated substanceat our facility which is CHLORINE.  The maximum inventory of chlorine is 14,000 lbs.
3. The Worst Case Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario including administrative controls and mitigation measures.
To perform the required offsite consequence analysis for our facility, we have used the look-up tables and equations provided by the EPA in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance. The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios:

Toxic Worst Case Analysis-
    The Worst case scenario involves a catastrophic release of chlorine from a cylinder broken or damaged outside the containment building while unloading. This scenario involves the release of 2000 lbs ( 1 cylinder ) of chlorine in a gaseous form over 10 minutes. The release rate ( lbs/min) is calculated to be 200. A distance to endpoint of 5.4 miles is obtained, which affects a residential population of 159,814 within this distance.

Toxic Alternative Case Analysis-
    The Alternative Case scenario involves the catastrophic release of chlorine form a cylinder while inside the containment building due to a damaged pipe or fitting. This scenario involves the release of 2000 lbs ( 1 cylinder) of chl

orine gas over a 10 minutes. Release rate is calculated to be 0.33 lbs./min. The distance to end point is 0.08 miles and the residential population is 1.

Flammables Worst Case Analysis-
   Not Applicable

Flammables Alternative Case Analysis
   Not Applicable

4. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program
   Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68. A number of processes at out facility are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29CFR1910.119. Our facility is also subjext to EPCRA Section 302 notification requrements.

Process Safety Information
   The Rock Island Water Treatment Plant maintains a record of safety information
Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts a "what-if" analysis by a team familiar with the process, every 5 years. Any findings are implemented and Operating Procedures are modified as needed.
Opearting Procedures
   Our facility maintains detailed operating procedures.The information is periodically reviewed and is readily accessible to plant personnel. 
Training
   The Rock Island Water Plant has a comprehensive training program in place. New employees receive basic classroom traing followed by on-the-job training. Refresher training is provide at least every 3 years.
Mechanical Integrity
   The Water Treatment Plant has a highly documented Preventive Maintenance program. Equipment deficiencies are indentified and corrected in a safe and timely manner. 
Management of Change
   Written procedures are in place at the Rock Island Water Treatment Plant to manage change in process chemicals. Technology, equipment, and procedures.
Pre Start-up Reviews-
   Pre Start-up safety reviews related to new processes and /or modifications are conducted as needed.
Compliance Audits
   Plant personnel conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least e

very 3 years.
Incident Investigation-
   The Rock Island Water Treatment Plant promptly investigates any incident that results in, or could result in a chemical accident or chemical release of a rugulated substance.All reports are maintained for at least 5 years.
Employee Participation
   The process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning preventions issues and to make recommendations for improvements.
Contractors
   When contractors are hired, pre contruction meetings are conducted to discuss issues such as safety. Contractors are informed of emergency response procedures for chlorine.
5. 5 Year Accident History
   there have been no accidental releases of chlorine during the past 5 year period.
6. Emergency Response Plan
   Facility is included in the written Community ER Plan. The local agency coordinating ER plan is the Rock Island Fire Department ( 309-732-2800).
7. Planned Changes to Inprove Safety
   Current plan has been reviewed and is up to date. No changes are planned at this time.
